# Draft:Warriors: The Broken Code

----
| author = Erin Hunter

| followed by = Warriors: A Starless Clan

Warriors: The Broken Code is the seventh story arc in the Warriors series by Erin Hunter. Published by HarperCollins from 2019 to 2021, this six-novel arc follows a supernatural crisis in which the warrior code fundamentally breaks down after Bramblestar's spirit is stolen and replaced by an imposter. The story explores themes of identity, spiritual corruption, and societal collapse through protagonists Rootspring (a SkyClan apprentice) and Shadowsight (a ShadowClan medicine cat). The arc marks significant changes to Clan governance and StarClan's relationship with living cats.
Development
The concept for The Broken Code originated from fan discussions about the rigidity of the warrior code. Editor Victoria Holmes stated in a 2019 interview that the team wanted to "test the code's limits" by creating a scenario where "following the rules becomes dangerous." The possession storyline was inspired by folklore about body-snatching spirits and the team's desire to "challenge the notion that StarClan is always right."
Author Kate Cary developed the imposter's manipulative tactics by studying real-world cult leaders, noting how they "twist language to control followers." The decision to make Bramblestar the possessed cat was controversial among fans but intentionally chosen because, as Holmes explained, "his strict adherence to the code made him the perfect vessel for corruption."
New illustrator Owen Richardson introduced a darker color palette for covers, reflecting the arc's themes. The writing team also created the "Place of No Stars" as a purgatory-like realm for codebreakers, distinct from the previously established Dark Forest.
Publication history
Lost Stars
Released in hardcover on 9 April 2019, this novel debuted at #1 on the New York Times Young Adult Bestseller list. It introduced the "imposter Bramblestar" mystery and Rootspring's perspective. The paperback followed on 3 December 2019.
The Silent Thaw
Published on 29 October 2019, this installment revealed Shadowsight's visions of the real Bramblestar trapped in the Dark Forest. Special editions included a bonus manga about Squirrelflight.
Veil of Shadows
Released on 7 April 2020, this book featured the shocking reveal of the imposter's identity. COVID-19 delays affected its initial print run.
Darkness Within
Published on 3 November 2020, this novel depicted the Clans' first attempt to banish the imposter. The paperback included an exclusive map of the Place of No Stars.
The Place of No Stars
Released on 6 April 2021, this penultimate installment followed a rescue mission into the afterlife. It became the series' fastest-selling book since Omen of the Stars.
A Light in the Mist
The finale published on 9 November 2021, concluded the possession storyline and reformed StarClan's hierarchy. A special box set with all six books and a poster released simultaneously.
Translations appeared in German (2020-2022), French (2021-2023), and Japanese (2022-2024). The German edition by Beltz & Gelberg notably altered the imposter's dialogue to sound more formally sinister.
Setting and characters
The arc expands the series' spiritual cosmology with these key elements:
The Place of No Stars: A new afterlife realm for cats who rejected both StarClan and the Dark Forest.
StarClan's Silence: The ancestral spirits temporarily lose connection with living cats.
Moonpool/Tunnel: The tunnel beneath the Moonpool becomes a physical bridge between worlds.
Major characters
Rootspring: A SkyClan apprentice who can see ghosts, serving as the imposter's primary opponent.
Shadowsight: A ShadowClan medicine cat whose visions accidentally enable the possession.
Bristlefrost: A ThunderClan warrior who sacrifices herself in the finale (later revealed to be permanently dead).
The Imposter: A spirit posing as Bramblestar, later revealed to be Ashfur from The Power of Three arc.
Squirrelflight: Becomes acting ThunderClan leader and central to the imposter's revenge plot.
Synopsis
Lost Stars
After Bramblestar dies from greencough, he miraculously returnsâ€”but acts strangely. Rootspring notices Bramblestar's spirit lingering near camp while an imposter occupies his body. Shadowsight realizes his visions helped enable the possession.
The Silent Thaw
The imposter manipulates the Clans into exiling "codebreakers," including cats who question him. Shadowsight discovers the real Bramblestar is trapped in the Dark Forest. Squirrelflight is framed for treason.
Veil of Shadows
The imposter is revealed to be Ashfur, a ThunderClan warrior killed years earlier. He seeks revenge on Squirrelflight for rejecting him. StarClan cuts off communication, fearing Ashfur's influence.
Darkness Within
The Clans attempt to drive out Ashfur but fail. Shadowsight is ostracized for his role in the possession. Rootspring and Bristlefrost begin a forbidden cross-Clan relationship.
The Place of No Stars
A team of living cats ventures into the afterlife to rescue Bramblestar. They discover Ashfur has been merging the Dark Forest with StarClan to control both realms.
A Light in the Mist
Bristlefrost sacrifices herself to drag Ashfur into oblivion, permanently dying in the process. StarClan reforms under new leadership, and the Clans revise the warrior code to be more flexible.
Themes
Spiritual Corruption: Ashfur weaponizes StarClan's authority to justify tyranny.
Identity: The imposter storyline questions what makes someone "themselves."
Grief and Closure: Bristlefrost's permanent death contrasts with the series' usual afterlife.
Reformation: The revised warrior code emphasizes intent over rigid rules.
Critical reception
The arc received widespread acclaim for its bold narrative risks:
Publishers Weekly praised its "unprecedented stakes" and called A Light in the Mist "a watershed moment for the series."
Kirkus Reviews noted Ashfur as "a villain who redefines the series' moral boundaries."
Some fans criticized Bristlefrost's permanent death as "too harsh" (School Library Journal), while others applauded its emotional impact.
The German translation won the 2022 Jugendbuchpreis for its "innovative handling of spiritual themes."
